Stayed at Kumu beach for 3 nights during our Sri Lankan holiday.  The location is a stunning spot.  The pool area extremely relaxing and perfect spot to watch the sunset.

The service is extremely slow and the communication is awful.  All staff is very friendly, but could enhance their communication and timeliness.  The hotel only has 1 chef, so breakfast every morning took well over an hour to serve.  If you plan to have lunch or dinner at the hotel, you need to alert the chef ahead of time so he can prepare.  The hotel does not serve hard liquor because they do not have a liquor license.  So do not expect to be having any sunset cocktails.  The menu is only local beer and wine.  The rooms are nice and spacious, but lacked any amenities and toiletries that would be standard for a hotel of this nature.  The beds were very comfortable.  Lastly, although they claim to have a spa on site, they have no massage therapists.  You need to book at least a day in advance so they can bring in massage therapists from their sister hotels.  The massage experience was extremely disappointing and inappropriate.  I have lived in Asia for 5 years and regularly having massages throughout travels.  I have never felt so violated in my life while having a massage.

Overall, although an idyllic location with stunning views, I would not return to the hotel nor recommend it.
title: Idyllic Location...terrible stay

text:
We visited Sri Lanka to celebrate our 10th Wedding Anniversary and therefore when looking at places to stay we wanted luxury and were prepared to pay the price. After reading the many great reviews on Tripadvisor and on the Stafford website we chose the Stafford Bungalow. 

A few days prior to departure we emailed the Stafford Bungalow as it was our first time to Sri Lanka and wanted to get directions to the bungalow. . After a few days of no response we emailed again, but again no response. We simply requested a good map with written directions to the bungalow as a few people had mentioned the difficulty in finding the place. I finally got an email back telling me to follow the directions on the website, those were not very clear so I asked again for written directions. This made us a little nervous but we still hoped they would contact us before our arrival in Sri Lanka and we even gave our phone number. Sadly, they did not, so on our morning of arrival we called the bungalow direct to get driving directions, luckily we were able to get what we thought were good directions. We had a local driver so we set out to Nuwara Eliya. 

After six hours in the car we arrived in Nuwara Eliya, the roads are narrow but it was a great experience. There were no directions from here to Ragla, which is another one hour drive in the afternoon from Nuwara Eliya. We called the Bungalow and they guided us to Ragla. On arriving in Ragla we had to call again to get directions to find the Bungalow. They guided us through the village and told us we would be at the white gate in about three minutes. We arrived at the gate and no one was there to greet us, we waited almost ten minutes after ringing the bell until it was opened. It was not a nice greeting as they knew we were almost there. 

The driveway into the property was truly beautiful and when we got out of the car and walked into the beautifully manicured gardens which was set up for afternoon told, we were very happy that we had arrived in such a beautiful place and wonderful garden.
The staff took our bags and gave us cool towels, we quickly went to the bathroom to freshen up. 

Back to the beautiful garden with fabulous views over the tea terraces, where we eagerly awaiting our “High Tea”. Our disappointment when they produced an old metal teapot with the string of the teabag hanging over, the cups were not even cups they were mugs and cheap ones at that. The bites and cakes were very pleasant as were the staff, but truly not luxury as it is described. We chose a tea plantation and expected a real high tea experience, it was very much lacking.  I headed straight for the shower which was a disappointment, there were dead flies on the window sills and a few on the floor, it was obvious no one had been in the room for a few nights at least. After my shower I grabbed for a towel which turned out to be an old hard towel which exfoliated me just like sandpaper, again not luxury. I went and explained the towel situation and asked for new ones for my husband, I was told that was all they had. 

After finishing our tea in that beautiful setting we retired to our room to unpack and relax before dinner. The room was a good size which is one of the reasons we chose it. 

At dinner that evening the manager came to chat and welcome us, after listening to him tell us about all the great things about the Stafford bungalow and how it is so highly ranked on tripadvisor, he also informed us about the morning tea trails hike, which we gladly booked. When he had finished telling us how fabulous the place was, I mentioned the difficulty we had when I emailed and asked directions, I also told him that when we finally got a response to look on the website, I mentioned that was not very nice and also not very welcoming. He then told me that no one ever has any issues finding the bungalow and we were here now.  Not the way a luxury property treats it guests, when they try to make a suggestion to help other guests in the future. As we were finishing dinner another family arrived and sat next to us and they had the same complaint about the driving directions but sadly for them when they called during dinner time no one answered, so they arrived very late.

We retired to our room, which by now we realized was a very tired room. I know its Sri Lanka but luxury is not like this, I sat on the bed and the whole bed was held up on a plank of wood, which creaked when you sat on it. The mattress was very old and soft, but our greatest disappointment were the sheets, like old flannel with bobbly bits on and even holes and stains. It was a huge disappointment but what could we do this late at night after a long day of travelling. 

Next morning we awoke very early to go on the Tea Hike. The manager met with us in the garden and we were the only ones hiking that day. The hike is truly one of the best things about this place, wandering through the plantation and watching the pickers work and seeing this part of beautiful Sri Lanka. During the walk the manager was very friendly and told us his whole life story and how he got to run the Stafford, he was very pleasant so I brought up the issues with him. Firstly, how we had emailed seeking good directions and had no response for days and as first timers to Sri Lanka, we were a little concerned but then to get a response to tell us to look at the direction on the website which were not very good, further disappointment. I then explained that our driver had to call 6 times from Nurwara Eliya to get clear directions to the place. He did not show any empathy and again just told us that most people find it very easily as he put us in our place and continued on telling us about the plantation. He really did not want to hear any issues as he kept telling us how great the place was.

There are a few great things about this place, the gardens, the setting in a beautiful tea plantation and the rest of the staff were wonderful. Sadly, there are too many downsides, some I have mentioned already, let me explain the rest of our stay.  It is a very long drive from Colombo, next time we would take the train and just hire a driver from there, much easier as the roads are not great and sometimes very busy with traffic. The crusty towels stayed with us for most of our stay as did the holes in the old bed sheets. The flowers that were in our room died the second morning and were never replaced. The flies in the shower also stayed with us even after I mentioned about the cleanliness. On our final night the manager came to our table as he would not be there in the morning when we left, he said that we hoped we had a lovely stay and could give them a good write up on Tripadvisor. I again mentioned that none of our issues were resolved, and on that note he said good night as he had to rush.
We were left at a total loss and retired to our room, we put together an email to the agency we booked through highlighting the issues and retired to bed. Next morning some lovely fluffy towels arrived in our room and at breakfast I received an email fro the Stafford head office, who wanted to call me to get the issues resolved. We were not able to connect that day, but I sent all the details of our non luxury trip to them with back up photos. We were finally happy that someone was listening to us.

A few days later a director from the parent company called me, he had received a full copy of my email and the photographs that I enclosed. He was very nice and very empathetic, but he had an agenda, his greatest concern was that I would not post any negative message on tripadvisor and also not to post the pictures of the dead flowers in the bedroom, the dead flies and unclean room, the holes in the bed sheet and duvet, the unclean bath sink and soap dish, the area just outside the garden with the rubbish dump and the litter everywhere beyond the bungalow walls but still in their grounds.

text:
My husband and I just returned from our two week honeymoon in Sri Lanka. We stayed at five different hotels (a mixture of luxury and rugged) while we were in the country... and KK was our big splurge. The last two nights of our honeymoon were spent at this hotel and although our room was beautiful, it was far and away the least favorite part of our trip. Actually, it was the ONLY bad part of our trip! 

While we were in Sri Lanka, we were overwhelmed by the kindness and warmth of the people we met. Unfortunately, this was not the case at KK. 

We were met by the hotel manager, who was very cold and formal. We tried to chat with him and as we walked to the room, we mentioned that it was our Honeymoon. He then proceeded to scold us (literally) for not having told them this (which we HAD, in earlier emails to the hotel) and said that had the hotel known that it was our honeymoon, we would have been upgraded or gotten special treatment, but that since we hadn't given them notice, we wouldn't be getting anything. He then said that they hotel was fully booked (which was a lie) and said that because of that, we wouldn't be getting an upgrade. He then turned around and left. 

Please let me be clear, my husband and I didn't ASK for any upgrades or gifts, nor did we expect them. We did not receive any special treatment at any other hotels, nor did we care. But by telling us this (very rudely), it made us feel as though we had lost something and were getting the short end of the stick. It was a horrible first impression and made us feel as though this beautiful room, that we were spending a lot of money on, was not as special as we had thought. 

The service never warmed up from there. Although the Tea Room where we stayed was beautiful (which, as an interior designer, was a lot of fun)... I had specifically requested the Garden Suite. When I was surprised to be put in a different room, I was told that that the Garden Suite wasn't available for both nights. Since we didn't want to have to move back and forth from room to room, we said that the Tea Suite was fine.... then we discovered that we weren't given a double bed! The Tea Suite has two twin beds pushed together, with a king sized fitted sheet holding them together, and we kept falling through the crack in the middle during the night. It was the most uncomfortable night's sleep... and didn't exactly add to the romance of a honeymoon to have two twin beds. I'm not one to nit-pick, but that's pretty absurd. Since we had been told that the hotel was "fully booked" we didn't complain, because we thought that this bed was our only option. To top it off... NO ONE EVER STAYED IN THE GARDEN SUITE! It was another lie from the manager. 

Additionally, the staff spoke such poor english that it made ordering anything very difficult. This was very odd, as we had been camping in the jungle just days earlier, and took the local busses around the country. Almost every Sri Lankan we met spoke enough english to communicate at a higher level than at KK. 

The staff was also SO formal and distant that the hotel felt cold and very different from all the other places we stayed in Sri Lanka... but this formality was paired with an odd sense of being nickle-and-dimed for everything, which usually only comes with budget hotels. We enjoyed cocktails for an hour before dinner, but were not given any bar snacks (nuts,chips,pretzels) without being told that it would be an extra charge of 700rpd... and ordering a cappucino or latte at breakfast is an extra charge as well. 

I used to work for a hotel group that managed 5 star resorts around the world, and the idea of charging someone for bar snacks who is spending $350-$700/night on their room PLUS all of their meals, is literally unheard of. 

Nothing about the experience felt connected to the beautiful culture or country, since we weren't being embraced in the Sri Lankan way. This treatment wasn't simply because this was an "upscale" hotel. We stayed at Tintagel in Colombo, which was the same price point, and were overwhelmed by their warmth, hospitality and incredible generosity. 

Unfortunately, our last two nights of our honeymoon left a bad taste in our mouths. I wish that we had skipped KK and saved the money. Most of all, I wish that I could have spent the last nights of my honeymoon at one of the other heavenly hotels in Sri Lanka. I hate that our final hours were in such an artificial and unwelcoming resort environment.

My friends (We were seven of us) who were lucky got their food after an hour the order of the unlucky ones was conveniently forgotten. Subsequently we moved to our rooms which had a generally poor level of cleanliness (Stains/ Dust/ Unhygienic Toilets) and creepers and crawlies all over. We reasoned that the Creepers would have been a function of the fact that it is in a Jungle but the lack of basic hygiene was unexplainable.

We shut the windows to keep the mosquitoes out and switched on the air conditioning which didn’t work. We then requested the Management to give us another room which they managed only by 10 pm i.e. after 3 hours (This despite the fact that we were the only guests in the property). While we could understand the fact that the ACs sometimes can go bad, what we didn’t understand was why it took the hotel 3 hours to give us an alternate room. 

Service levels at dinner time added insult to injury. (A few of us had to make to with Bread and Butter).

While checking out the next day, I thought I'd speak with Mr. Cooper and share my experience. His reply was "It's a Jungle what else do you expect". I replied that after paying in excess of 300 dollars a night at the very least basic room service, hygienic rooms and functioning appliances. He replied "So what do you want a discount?" almost as if he was reprimanding me for bringing this to his notice. I replied in the affirmative to which his answer was that "May be my staff didn't serve you well enough as they were appalled by the way you were talking to each other" I said if we weren't rude to your staff what has the language we talk to each other in got to do with them not serving us. 

He then went on to add that you are Indians and "Indian's are loud" and Hindu's are very different from Buddhists and he finds it impossible to deal with them. 

I told Mr. Cooper "If that's how you feel, please put a board out saying Indian's not allowed", paid my balance and walked away in disgust.

Sri Lanka is an awesome place to visit just don't make the mistake of staying at Kahanda Kanda. If you do be prepared for bad service and poor house-keeping and for heaven’s sake please don’t complain else be prepared for racial slurs.

We booked 14 nights over Christmas in a Plunge Pool room on an all-inclusive basis, but left a day early. The best asset the hotel has is it's general staff, who are friendly, efficient and gave a good level of service.The pool and sun loungers are good, and the grounds are well maintained.

Our room was well appointed, but very dark. The dehumidifier cannot cope with the humidity from the plunge pool, which makes the room very damp. All our clothes smelled musty when we got home, so we had to wash things we hadn't even worn.

But what really let the hotel down was the kitchen. My wife and I have travelled extensively over the past 25 years across the world, including remote parts of Africa and Asia, and therefore stayed in many hotels. We have visited Sri Lanka twice before, once touring, and last Christmas at another 5* hotel. We have never suffered with food poisoning on any of our trips. Following the Christmas Eve buffet at this hotel, my wife spent Christmas day with chronic diarhoea, listlessness and loss of appetite. Two days later, I had the same. We decided to avoid the buffet, but on the 13th night of our stay my wife got food poisoning again, this time with added extreme vomiting. We also heard of other guests having stomach problems. Not wanting to be ill on our journey home and feeling we could not trust the food any more, we spoke to our excellent local rep Kristi and arranged to leave a day early.

Another concern was the kitchen's lack of confidence about what foods contain gluten. My wife is allergic to gluten and the chefs seemed very confused at times. They seem to believe that gluten is in Hollandaise sauce, as at one breakfast she asked for Eggs Benedict and got poached eggs on gluten-free bread. One evening she was served curry with poppadoms that were removed at the last second. The Head Chef one day asked me whether chickpea flour was ok, and another day insisted that green peas contain gluten. We have never encountered these issues at other hotels and it is a real concern for people with allergies.

I somehow doubt that the hotel will accept this criticism, and will say they asked us if we wanted to see a doctor. When you are staying in a supposed luxury hotel, you should not get ill in the first place. It's a shame because it's the one reason I can guarantee we will never return to this hotel.

The mise en place for all dishes are done well in advance as done in any hotel around the world. The resort does not serve left over dishes and do not agree with the clients comment ‘what we presume was, last night’s left over curry’.
 
Being located adjacent to the sea it takes a considerable effort and time to up keep the building in perfect shape in the Monsoon period with the humidity factor and apologize for the inconvenience caused to the clients by the damp conditions.
 
Beach cleaning is done on a daily basis by the hotel and have already taken the initiative and placed waste bins , cloth hanger's and a bicycle stand for the local community using the beach to help in keeping the beach clean.

text:
Unfortunately the most important comment on the hotel - if you like good food, do not eat here!! We saw a few negative reviews remarking the same, but also many stating they were impressed with the food - we listen to the wrong reviews and stayed here. I really cannot stress enough how disappointed we were with the dinners. We stayed in Sri Lanka for 2 weeks, The Fortress for 3 nights, and the dinners were to the worst standard for the whole trip, and a lot more expensive.
For the first night we ordered the signature Sri Lankan curry dishes - one chicken and one fish. We asked for this not too spicy (after being given the choice by the waiter). The curry was far too spicy, and arrived 30 seconds after we had finished our starter - this only possible by the fact the curry had been made earlier in the evening, and left ready to serve diners. We asked the waiter for something less spicy as we could not eat the food - he was more than willing to oblige, took our curries away, and returned with new plates. The meat had been removed from the spicier sauce, and put into some sort of coconut milk sauce, which lacked any flavour, colour, or complexity you would expect from a 5* hotel. We had to send this back as well - it was simply not something you could eat and enjoy. By this point, all rather bemused at the cooking, we opted for some cold starters.. The waiter did remove the disappointing curries from the bill, but by this point, we knew what we had let ourselves in for! 
We tried the fine dining menu one evening, which again was disappointing. While it seemed the chefs had taken longer to prepare the food, it was simply not worth the money, or impressive at all. 
In other food news - the selection at breakfast was good. Hit up the made to order egg station for something fresh. Or you can try, what we presume was, last nights left over curry! 
Pool food was limited, but much better than the dinner. The pizza was the best on the menu! You can use the hotel app for a discount, however we found sometimes this did not work and we were left waiting 45 minutes for our drinks - again the staff apologised and offered us a free drink at dinner to compensate. 
As for the rest of the hotel - the building has some natural history, and is laid out well. The pool area overlooking the ocean, and some wild swimming turtles, again was lovely. We did feel however the hotel could be doing more to keep the adjacent beach clean. 
Our room was huge, but smelt musty, and the corridor to the room was often wet (not sure why) - one day after the hallways had been painted we were met with water / paint on the floor. Again not something you would expect from a 5* hotel. 
The staff were probably the redeeming factor here - they were helpful and polite. But it's hard to ignore the shortcomings of the hotel, especially at this price. For what else is on offer in Sri Lanka, we were disappointed to have chosen this hotel. 
I would not recommend this hotel, and unfortunately would not return.
title: Worst food we ate in Sri Lanka :(

Despite the unmistakable sound of running water, he proceeded to go deeper into the room and look through the clear glass door, seeing me in a state of complete vulnerability. It was extremely evident that someone was in the shower, but he wanted to look anyway. The sense of violation and trauma I felt in that moment is hard to put into words. I wanted to leave immediately, but it was our last night there so I just told myself to get through this one night.

The hotel’s initial response was wholly inadequate. They offered to comp our dinner and “upgrade” me to a similar room with a larger balcony and better view, as if that could somehow rectify what had happened. It wasn’t until after my tour agent intervened did the hotel refund the full cost of my stay.

The follow-up correspondence from the hotel’s General Manager included the usual assurances: that this was an isolated incident, and that staff training would be improved. While I truly hope they follow through on these promises, I feel that basic staff protocols, such as not entering a room when someone is in the shower, should not require additional training. They are common sense. Please, do better.

Salad bar - full marks.

Vegetarian mains: 
No egg kothu rotti or plain vegetable kothu rotti in Sri Lanka is unforgivable. String hopper kothu is a cheap less effort alternative. If your chefs are too tired to make a light onion gravy in order to make a veg kothu rotti - they should find new jobs.

I asked the chef for a normal veg kothu rotti whilst he was making more meat kothu even though the dish to store it was already full. He said he couldn’t. Why - I have no idea. Laziness?

Channa curry - channa was not cooked through. Also the spices were still semi-raw and it was like eating a can of chickpeas in tomato soup. A number of diners complained that you were serving channa and korma but had no Indian breads to accompany it. Where is the naan, roti, chapati, dosa??

To the chefs of cinnamon wild. It is 2023. The world is not just Brit/Americans from the 1950s after a roast meat.

The amount of meats on offer compared to the vegetarian mains is inexcusable and diminishes your brand. No paneer, no veg skewers, no tofu, no soya meats. It is 2023. Lift your game.

Sri Lanka is thought of as a food lovers paradise but I have been really, really disappointed. You can’t keep getting away with spiceless noodles and bread rolls and dhal for your vegetarian guests. 

I love the hotel but am really disappointed in the food. That is a significant part of the experience. At this price point and for this brand - I expect better. Your chefs need to be fired and hire people who understand that every medical doctor in the western world advocates that their patients eat meat less than once/week for basic health reasons. Do better. Make as much effort for vegetarians as you do for meat eaters and be as creative or more! 

Very disappointed.

What could have been a tranquil, wellness-focused stay turned into a frustrating, isolating experience. We checked out feeling more drained than when we arrived.

I wouldn’t recommend Niyagama House to anyone looking for value, comfort, or authentic hospitality. There are far better options in and around Galle.

text:
So, I have a lot to say about this place; I just spent one week here. I’m 48 and a solo traveller. I have been to a few yoga retreats before as I find it a good way to connect with other solo travellers; but that was not the vibe here. I’ll break my experience into sections.

Facilities
The hotel looks excellent, very clean, my room was beautiful with a lovely sea view, cannot fault it. The pool was well maintained and clean.

Food
As expected at an ayervadic retreat, it was a little bland but there was a decent range of choice and dosha types were well signed. Could have benefited from being clear if something contained dairy as some items said lactose free but I wasn’t sure that they were dairy free. The waiting staff were friendly enough….more so on last day and night!

Pool area
The attendant worked so hard and was genuinely friendly. 

Trips
There were a few advertised included excursions but I saw no evidence of the guided beach walk, and temple visit was on my last day but not the Sunday I arrived so I missed that.
I also asked them to arrange a whale watching trip for me which they charged $150 for. I looked it up on Viator and it retailed at $50 so I refused to pay 3x the amount. The hotel said the tour company gave them prices and I’m inclined to believe that was partly true, plus they added their own mark up. In the end they agreed I should pay $90… not ideal, but still better. If you want a trip, book directly, they do free hotel pick up on all boat trips from Mirissa.

Treatments
Now these might be ok if you have never had proper ayervadic treatment but, if like me you have, you will be awfully disappointed. The therapists are very overworked and it shows. I’d be prepared to bet they had a 2 day training course in massage as each treatment was more about how much oil they could cover me in rather than any focus on energy flow etc. the therapists were all very nice though and did their best so I feel unkind saying this. Also there is a sauna treatment which is basically a coffin with a head hole, it looks beautiful but I’d suggest if you are slightly claustrophobic, ask the therapist to stay in the room, as I was left sweating in it for 10 minutes and had to shout for someone to come  and let me out (now I’m British, we aren’t big on speaking up, so this was not easy!) 

Yoga
The Teacher said some informative things but he repeated himself 3 or 4 times while different people arrived in each class. May I suggest he types some information on the 8 limbs of yoga, asanas, pranayama and the nadis so it can be included in a welcome pack to save him repeating it? In a 1 hour class, we only got off the mat for about 10 minutes so not the flow you might be expecting. The evening is more breath work which I enjoyed more but found difficult to sit for 1 hour due to my own injury.

Local area
It is not actively encouraged to leave, I can see why. I would have preferred advice such as, if you want to go to local town eat banana and drink coconut rather than feeling like I was escaping. I took public busses to local towns and had the best time there.
The small bay is also a tiny walk and is great for a swim.
I liked Galle and Mirissa. 

Dr advice
I very much appreciated the take away advice I was given, that was very helpful to take forward. 
I did a full cleanse and I’m not sure if it was a bit gimicky or genuinely good for health. There were no other panchakarmas offered other than sitting in the toilet for most of the day, so consider before you go if you would like this as I was taken aback and agreed without really considering it.

Overall 
I feel it is shiny, clean and superficially nice. The staff smile and go through the motions but there was no genuine warmth, other than the pool guy and one male therapist. People are sat to eat individually so there is no encouraged sense of community. No games or evening chats are available so it’s dinner then bed. 
I would agree it is a nice hotel but I would not recommend it as an ayervadic or yoga retreat.

text:
Well, our stay at the Riff Hikkaduwa ended as it started, with disappointment.
We arrived at the airport and looked for our pre-booked transfer, we couldn’t see it.  We then had to go and buy a local SIM card to call the hotel to ask where our driver was, only to be told that we hadn’t booked a transfer.  Maybe at this stage a different answer could have been given .... we were then told they would get back to us ASAP - by this time (hot, sweaty and nearly an hour after landing), we just said could they sort a ride for us. We then had to go back through all our emails to find our booking and the hotel confirmation of said booking (the hotel should have done this). They then agreed that it was their error and covered the cost of the transfer.  Didn’t really deal with the fact that instead of arriving calm and cool we were hot and sweaty and fed up after a three hour journey in a basic van.
We finally arrived at the hotel and the location is perfect with beautiful views to the ocean.  We then had a lovely lunch and all was good.
However, there was more disappointment to come.  Our Room smelled musty and of drains when you ran the shower - we told housekeeping about this every day, nothing was ever done about it, the same with the shower which overflowed into the bathroom - obviously there are blocked drains somewhere which need to be sorted. Also, no toiletries were replenished at all during our stay, I mentioned again to housekeeping and whilst I applaud the fact that they use refillable containers, they really should refill them daily.  Finally, the towel service was random, one day we ended up with a damp dirty pillowcase ( not ours) left on the sofa along with one hand towel and a flannel (we hadn’t left any towels on the floor so expected to re-use the ones we had for another day!).   That being said, the rooms are a good size and the showers are really nice.  
Breakfast was another random area as far as service was concerned.  The offering here is very good with a nice selection although they should stop doing the French pastries, they do not resemble any pastry I have ever seen.  The problem comes when you expect to a) get what you order and b) expect it to taste the same as the previous day!  Every day there would be at least one thing we ordered that didn’t turn up despite asking about 5 times,although all orders appear to be keyed into a handheld device.
Dinner on our second day was not good, at best it was mediocre.  We ordered the same dish as we did for lunch the previous day, what turned up was probably leftovers from lunch, aspects of the dish were completely missing and it had a totally different taste.
We then had the worst seafood platter I have ever had, all of the items were over cooked and nothing was provided to get meat out of the crab, there were no finger bowls and no napkins and the salad that came along with it was rotten (more leftovers I suspect).
We then asked about our transfer back to the airport, to be told again there was nothing booked.  We were originally quoted LHR 10,000 this suddenly became LHR 17,000 because we were doing a last minute booking and it was via the hotel (even though we did book).  We then agreed to pay our driver direct and the price went back down to 12,000.
Whilst a number of these things are petty once they are grouped together and happen day after day they are wearing.  I don’t expect this kind of customer service from a top class hotel.
I understand they have only been open for 4 months.  However, I did not pay a discounted rate so I expected everything to be as I would expect from a 5 star hotel.
Our final disappointment was on our final day, we needed to get to breakfast at 7am (the same time it is every day) to be ready for transport to the airport at 7.30am.  This was all agreed and communicated with the hotel the day before. We got to breakfast only to be told it wasn’t starting until 7.30am (although it always started at 7am and nothing had been said about a later start).
We then asked if we could get a cup of tea or coffee which they agreed to.  In the dining room we noticed another guest was having breakfast, suffice to say the tea/coffee didn’t turn up at all and so we again complained.  We were then provided with a takeaway breakfast - not quite the same when you had had a hot drink and meal in mind.  It contained the inedible pastries!
There are other issues as well that could maybe be overlooked because of the great location if it wasn’t for the other issues. 
There is not enough wardrobe space in the rooms, they need a set of drawers at least.  Also the only mirror is in the bathroom which is annoying if you are both trying to get ready.  A full length mirror would have been nice too.
The power goes out regularly and then you need to do a ridiculous amount of trying all the switches to get everything up and running again - very annoying when it happens in the middle of the night and you wake up sweltering because the air con is off.
The lighting on the stairs is only on sometimes and because of the nature of the wood used it is sometimes difficult to see the stairs properly.
Also, there is no lounge to speak of, there are some chairs set up in the lobby but they are not very comfortable and the bar there is very rarely manned so you could be waiting a long time before you get a drink.
We did complain and the hotel very kindly supplied us with 2 free bottles of wine and some cheese and port in our rooms.  This was very much appreciated.  However, the issues still continued, it would have been so much nicer if the next day when we ordered breakfast we actually got everything that we ordered! 
I have looked at all the reviews from previous guests and I cannot believe that we are the only ones to experience these issues.  Maybe we just expected too much?
Sri Lanka is a beautiful country and the stretch of coastline where the hotel is located is perfect.  However, if you want service consistent with a 5 star hotel I would suggest you choose a different one to this.
title: Beautiful location shame about the service

I stayed here for 3 days in March 2022. Having read the wondering reviews, I couldn’t wait to end my holiday here. This hotel is by far the worst one I have ever stayed in in Sri Lanka- a beautiful country which I have visited frequently over the years.

Upon arrival, the check in process was extremely unorganised. We had paid for a room with a plunge pool. We were instead shown to a riverside room with no pool. When I asked where the pool was, the employee said we hadn’t paid for that type of room. My husband had to repeatedly send proof of our booking which clearly stated we had paid for a plunge pool room. We were moved to the correct room type around 30 minutes later.

When we got the the correct room, it absolutely stunk of smoke. The furniture downstairs in the villa was extremely outdated and there were hairs all over the sofa. The kitchen area was covered in ants and hadn’t been cleaned in a very long time. When I went upstairs to check the bedding, there was lots of dead ants and insects under the sheets. The staff were quick to change this and provide an oil burner to mask the smell of smoke.

I would express major security concerns with the villas on the beach. Anyone can freely walk past and around the hotel- there are no fences or separation. On one of the days I was lying at garden area in front of the villa I was staying at. I noticed two local men walking past but thought nothing of it. The next day, they returned and we’re taking photographs of me whilst sunbathing. This made me feel extremely uncomfortable so we immediately reported this to the security and management. We were then moved room for the duration of our stay due to safety concerns. The properties have sliding doors which are extremely easy to force open.

We went to the ‘bar’- I use this term loosely as it is an extremely run down area with old discoloured furniture, we had our next disappointment. We had booked an all inclusive package. The bar tender was quick to tell us that we had very select items available to us, which I immediately spoke to a manager about. Nowhere did it state that we would not be allowed ‘premium’ (imported) beers and spirits. The manager agreed and allowed my husband to have imported beer. The staff repeatedly asked us for our booking whilst we were there to ‘check our package’.

Each night the food was average. One night there was a buffet and it was horrendous- full of children running around and extremely limited food choice. We ordered burgers from the lunch menu each day as we knew the evening food would not be good.

When we went to book a taxi to the airport, the manager tried to charge us $70 for a 20 minute journey which is daylight robbery considering we had travelled from Unawatuna (a 2 and a half hour drive) for $25 via taxi. When I complained, he said it was due to the luxury vehicle (a Mercedes van?)! We were able to source our own transport for $20. Absolutely disgusting that they could try to extort guests in this way.

The resort is old and outdated. There are mattresses and cots lying around communal areas. There are lots of ants in the rooms. There are very limited reviews on this hotel and what has been shared by others is not a true reflection. I would never recommend this place to anyone.

The only positives I could draw from the hotel are two friendly members of staff - Amindu and Jaliya.

text:
The location was very remote. If you are staying here, please expect to have to get a tuk tuk everyday to and from the main towns such as Unawatuna. Tuk tuk drivers wait outside the hotel and charge roughly 10x the price you would normally expect to pay in Sri Lanka. They are taking advantage of the fact that this is a 5 star hotel and being so remote. These guys are allegedly nothing to do with the hotel, but conveniently sit directly outside and when you ask reception for a tuk tuk - miraculously one of the guys outside comes in to collect you. I suspect the hotel is working with them and splitting inflated profits. 

If you are considering booking a taxi to get you to and from Tabula Rasa, please don’t book with the hotel. They wanted to charge us £120 one way when in reality, this is double the price of booking a transfer through the likes of booking.com or any other reputable transfer company, which offered this service for £60 one way. This is what we chose to do as it was far cheaper. 

The food, be it fairly good, is expensive. Much more than you would expect to pay in other hotels in Sri Lanka. We opted to pay extra to have breakfast provided within our stay. You would naturally assume that water would be included at breakfast right? Well, not exactly. The hotel charges $2 per bottle of water, which I find absolutely disgraceful and disgusting. They are capitalising on the fact you need to drink water in such a hot climate. No complimentary water in the room either, this was also chargeable at $2 a bottle. An utter disgrace as you have already paid for breakfast so this should be included. 

The general condition of the hotel was tired. Flaking paint, rough edges and generally tired interiors can be seen everywhere. Within our room we had broken picture frames, marked walls and general obvious areas of heavy use. This place really does need a freshen up and refurbishment. We have since learned that the hotel has chosen to build another “premium” room instead of improving the current rooms. Very disappointing. 

Staff were pleasant. I overheard what I assume was the owner one day whilst swimming in the pool, having a go at a couple of members of staff. This was done loudly and I could hear every word. Not professional or pleasant to overhear as a paying guest. 

Cleanliness of the room was not good. We paid a lot of money for our room which was priced at $450 per night, to have it properly cleaned would have been appreciated. Instead, our room, was simply cat licked leaving dust and debris through the room each day. Also, furniture throughout the hotel and within our room was old and tired. Sweat marks cover the pool lounge cushions. We had a sofa within our room and a daybed near the window. Each of which were again covered in stains and marks. Again, more complacency from the owners in not ensuring rooms were up to standard. Very disappointing indeed. 

We mentioned to the hotel that this was our honeymoon when booking. We were disappointed to find that the hotel had not made any special efforts to reflect this. Even a simple a acknowledgement would have been sufficient, but nothing. 

Overall we were very disappointed with Tabula Rasa and felt that with some care and attention from the owners, has the potential to become a top hotel.
title: Not worth the money

text:
I decided to book the Hilltop villa for exclusive use at a rate of 350 USD after reading all the wonderful reviews about the place, the staff and their service in the Trip advisor website.  I regret that this was the worst decision I made for my vacation. 

My family of 4 arrived at the villa in the afternoon on July 31st 2013. This was the last day of our 2 week long vacation in Sri Lanka. We had spent the last two weeks in properties such as Kadju House in Tangalle and South Point Cottage in Ahangama. We were expecting similar standards of hospitality and service at Jims Farm Villa.  About myself – I am an expat working for the United Nations and have stayed in several hotels and villas around the world.

When we arrived, the manager, Jesse, unexpectedly mumbled a plethora of options for rooms and rates upon our arrival, despite the fact that we had booked the entire Hilltop villa for exclusive use. While we were initially confused, Jesse later mentioned that he provided these options to us for our own advantage. So, picture 5 people including Jesse standing in the patio of the Spice Garden Villa in the afternoon heat drinking papaya juice (with added sugar) as Jesse quickly mumbles out rooms and rates options to us.  He offered us two rooms at the Spice Garden Villa for a rate of 160 USD per room half board (i.e. including dinner and breakfast).  He stated that the rate of 350 at the Hilltop villa did not include any meals, which we were already aware of. While we had booked the Hilltop villa for exclusive use, given that Jesse was the one who initiated the conversation to urge us to explore other options, we nevertheless decided to check out the rooms at both the Hilltop and Spice Garden Villas and arrive at a final decision. We were also wondering if it would be possible to book a triple room at Spice Garden Villa as that would be an economical option for us because we were planning on going on an excursion and would return to the villa late in the night.  We asked one of the boys who showed us the room to check this with Jesse. The boy returned back stating that Jesse cannot come and he wants to see us in the office.  This by itself was rude hospitability in my opinion. So, I walk to Jesse’s office where he is seated behind the desk and I opt to sit down in one of the plastic chairs in the corner.  I ask him about the triple room option and he quoted another rate without providing any breakup of the amounts.  Totally confused by now, I ask for the break up of the rates and also wanted to double check the rates in the website but I could not as there was no internet at the office. I then received a curt reply from Jesse “so you don’t trust me”.  I was shocked by this statement. Jesse then mumbled a few abusive words and said that he would not offer me any options now. He would only offer me the Hilltop Villa that I had booked for. I had to argue with him and get a clear picture of the rates while my family of 3 (including my 7 year old child) was standing outside.  This was a very embarrassing situation for me and the experience spoilt my day. I spoke to Jesse about his rudeness and he quickly apologized and provided me a clear breakup of the rates for a triple room.

The rates for Jims Farm Villa are already published in their website.  It would be beneficial to have a printed pamphlet of the room rates as well as the charges for breakfast and dinner at the office.  It would also be nice to have the guests sit down at ease when they arrive and go over the charges with them in a leisurely fashion rather mumbling rates and charges and confusing clients in a hurried manner, especially those who have booked villas for exclusive use. 

Further, no matter what, usage of curt replies, abusive language and arrogant tone and body language is just not acceptable in the hospitality industry. Jesse apologized for his behavior and mentioned “no hard feelings” to me when I was checking out.  However, this is not going to undo the damage done by him to my vacation.

The staffs at Jim’s Farm Villa are a nice bunch of young boys who are courteous, unlike their manager. We were served some delicious Sri Lankan curry and rice – the papaya curry that we had was one of the best during our trip to Sri Lanka.  

We encountered some problems with the television in our room and there was no satellite reception. The staff came but and tried to fix this but were not successful. My kid loves to watch cartoons and while it is understandable that satellite reception did not exist because of the strong wind, we asked if we could use the room next door for 30 minutes to watch TV.  The staff came by and said that the room is booked (obviously I am guessing Jesse must have told them to say that).  How could the room have been booked when Jesse has just quoted us a rate for 2 rooms few minutes ago? They offered some DVDs instead (most of the DVDs were for teenage children and exceeded the age bracket of my kid).

While the staff was very helpful, discrete hospitality is lacking at the villa. Even if harmless or unintentional, I would not appreciate 2 boys staring at us eat for the entire period of our lunch. 
This is however a minor issue (compared to the issue with the manager) and can be easily fixed.
Wireless internet was not working in our room. This is contrary to what is stated in their website. When we checked in, we saw that the bathroom in our room was full of dead insects. 

The location is nice and remote – but I enjoyed some other plantation villas much better during my vacation. Overall, given the shockingly rude hospitality of the manager and poor facilities (problems with television and wireless internet), we have ranked this place as terrible.
Please bear in mind that experiences differ from person to person. The couple in my next room seemed to be enjoying the place. There are several excellent reviews about the property and praises about the picturesque location.  However, having travelled all over the world and stayed in comparable villas, I could see a marked difference in the levels of hospitality and service.  Hospitality is not just about picturesque locations, charming tuk tuk rides across villas, and good food.  The real and genuine intent to serve matters a lot. Jims Farm Villa has the potential – only if management takes action to spruce up service levels and send Jesse back to grooming school to learn basic etiquette and customer handling skills.

No matter what response or apology to a response management provides, any prudent or self respecting person cannot expect hospitality to take such a severe beating. I thought it is important to write a candid review based on real experiences. 

I will be creating a blog/web site about my experiences in Sri Lanka as well as writing a book shortly – will surely factor in my experiences about my stay at Jims Farm Villa. 
Please send me an email at sridevijay@gmail.com if you want to know more about our stay.
